lines.text:
[looking at the dead body of Lucrezia Borgia's husband]
Would you say the dead man made a reluctant corpse?
A loose tongue soon loses its mouth, Captain Orsini.
A wise tongue never needs to repeat itself, Don Esteban, nor does a competent assassin.
It is my belief that everything, even death, can be turned into profit.
the outcome justifies the act. Have you the stomach for greatness?
The stomach and the appetite.

[to Andrea]
I never cut a throat without knowing whose it is or why I'm cutting it.

[responding to a noise outside her cottage which has disturbed her dog]
Mice, rabbits, cats - a widow's dog never rests.

[after getting a shove from behind from Borgia]
My Lord!
My garden is filled with beautiful women and you stand here like a brooding nemisis!
I was thinking.
Good. Practice makes perfect.
[Walking away]
You should listen though. You may learn something.
I promise you I know how to hate.
Or love, the twin of hate.
I believe that I was born and that I must die, and that I must make the best of what lies between the two extremes.
Heroism is a shallow thing, Madonna, if it isn't rooted in wisdom.
I don't intend to be wise; I can only be what I am.
I asked to be taken to Duke Cesare Borgia.
By his orders I sit in his seat.
Well, sit lightly, my friend, lest you damage your brains.

[to Andrea]
I've lived seventy years, and know in spite of the poets, youth is not the happiest season.
I've discovered the dead don't always pay best.

[Describing a man who would fit his requirements as an agent]
... be as quick at deceit as a fox. He must have the grace of a dancer; the wrist of an assassin. He must have little regard for good faith, yet by his astuteness, be able to confuse men's minds. He must have confidence in himself, yet not let that confidence render him incautious. He must charm as a snake charms a bird, yet he must make no friends, except those who can be of use to him and, for the same reason, although he may make use of love, he must not love."
